skill.name: commit-prepare
skill.description: Prepare git commit messages following conventional commits. Activates on: commit, prepare commit, commit this, commit message, ready to commit, stage and commit
skill.summary: Prepare git commit messages following conventional commits. Activates on: commit, prepare commit, co...
skill.author: ByronWilliamsCPA

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and instructions for commit message generation. No executable code, no network access, no credential theft capabilities. The git commands documented are expected functionality for a commit helper skill.

content.value_statement: Generate standardized commit messages that improve project history readability and enable automated changelog generation. This skill analyzes your staged changes and creates properly formatted conventional commits with appropriate type detection.
actual_capabilities: Analyze staged changes and suggest appropriate commit types
Generate conventional commit messages with subject, body, and footer
Detect breaking changes and mark them appropriately
Handle multi-line commit messages using HEREDOC syntax
Check for secrets or credentials before committing
limitations: Does not automatically stage files without user confirmation
Does not create or modify branch structures
Requires user approval before executing git commit

use_cases.title: Standardize commit history
use_cases.description: Generate consistent, readable commit messages that improve project history and enable automated releases

use_cases.title: Enforce commit conventions
use_cases.description: Ensure all team contributions follow conventional commits format for changelog automation

use_cases.title: Prepare release notes
use_cases.description: Create properly structured commits that feed into semantic versioning and release pipelines

prompt_templates.title: Basic commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Commit my staged changes with a conventional commit message describing what was modified

prompt_templates.title: Feature commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Prepare a commit message for a new feature I just added. Analyze my staged changes and generate an appropriate feat: type commit

prompt_templates.title: Breaking change
prompt_templates.prompt: I made breaking changes to my API. Create a conventional commit with the exclamation mark notation and explain the migration needed

prompt_templates.title: Multi-file commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze all my staged changes. If they cover multiple concerns, suggest splitting into separate commits with appropriate messages

output_examples.input: Prepare a commit message for my staged changes in src/auth/oauth.py
output: Looking at your staged changes in src/auth/oauth.py:
- Added token refresh logic with retry mechanism
- Included exponential backoff for failed refresh attempts
Implement automatic token refresh when access token expires.
Includes retry logic with exponential backoff.
Shall I commit with this message?

best_practices: Review the generated message before confirming the commit to ensure accuracy
Use breaking change notation (!) when modifying public APIs or removing features
Keep the subject line under 50 characters using imperative mood
anti_patterns: Using vague commit messages like 'fixed bug' or 'updated code'
Skipping the body when changes are non-trivial and need context
Not checking for secrets or sensitive data before committing

faq.question: What are conventional commits?
faq.answer: Conventional commits are a standardized format that prepend commit messages with type prefixes like feat:, fix:, or docs: for changelog automation.

faq.question: Does this skill push to remote?
faq.answer: No, this skill only prepares and executes local commits. It suggests git push after successful commits but requires explicit user approval.

faq.question: What commit types are supported?
faq.answer: feat, fix, docs, refactor, test, perf, chore, ci, and style. Each has specific use cases defined in the skill documentation.

faq.question: Is my code data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only reads git status and diffs to analyze changes. Your code is never sent to external servers or stored anywhere.

faq.question: Can I use this with GitHub CLI?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill works with standard git commands and is compatible with gh CLI for creating commits and pull requests.

faq.question: How is this different from git commit templates?
faq.answer: This skill actively analyzes your staged changes and suggests appropriate messages. Git templates only provide static prompts for you to fill in.
